If $\mathbb{R}^2$ is finitely coloured then must there exist some colour class which contains the vertices of a rectangle of every area?



Graham \cite{Gr80} has shown that this is true if we replace rectangle by right-angled triangle. The same question can be asked for parallelograms. It is not true for rhombuses.

This is false; Kova\v{c} \cite{Ko23} provides an explicit (and elegantly simple) colouring using 25 colours such that no colour class contains the vertices of a rectangle of area $1$. The question for parallelograms remains open.

This problem has been formalised in Lean as part of the Google DeepMind Formal Conjectures project.




References


[Gr80] Graham, R. L., On partitions of ${\bf E}^{n}$. J. Combin. Theory Ser. A (1980), 89-97.

[Ko23] Kova\vC, V., Coloring and density theorems for configurations of a given volume. arXiv:2309.09973 (2023).
